title: Shamima Begum at ‘real risk’ of death after losing UK citizenship
text:
Isis bride Shamima Begum is fighting the Home Office decision to strip her of British citizenship (Picture: PA/BBC)

Losing her British citizenship put Isis bride Shamima Begum at ‘real risk’ of torture or death, a court has heard.

The east London schoolgirl who travelled to Syria to marry an Islamic State fighter has today launched a legal challenge against the decision to remove her citizenship.

Shamima, now 20, left the UK with two other teenagers in February 2015 and lived under Isis rule for more than three years.

She was found, nine months pregnant, in a Syrian refugee camp in February this year.

Former home secretary Sajid Javid stripped her of her British citizenship after she asked to return to the UK, a decision her lawyers argue was unlawful as it rendered her stateless.

Such a decision is lawful only if an individual is entitled to citizenship of another country.

Today, lawyers acting on her behalf began proceedings against the Home Office before the High Court and the Special Immigration Appeals Commission (SIAC).

Shamima Begum’s third child died days after being born in a Syrian refugee camp (Picture: ITV)

SIAC is a specialist court which hears challenges to decisions to remove someone’s British citizenship on national security grounds.

Advertisement

At the start of the four-day hearing in London, Tom Hickman QC said the situation in the al-Roj camp in which Shamima is currently being held is ‘incredibly fragile and dangerous’.

In written submissions, he described conditions at the camp – where Shamima’s third child died in March – as ‘wretched and squalid’.

He added: ‘The tragic death of the appellant’s infant child demonstrates that fact.’

Mr Hickman said Shamima – who is of British-Bangladeshi heritage – ‘is not considered a national of Bangladesh and was therefore rendered stateless by the deprivation decision’.

He submitted that the Bangladeshi courts ‘would determine that the appellant did not automatically acquire Bangladeshi citizenship having been born outside Bangladesh as a UK citizen by birth’.

He referred to evidence from an expert in Bangladeshi law, who says that it is ‘nearly impossible that any court in Bangladesh would rule against the government’, which has publicly denied Shamima is a citizen of Bangladesh.

Shamima Begum passing through security barriers at Gatwick Airport (Picture: AFP/Getty)

Shamima married an Isis fighter 10 days after arriving in Islamic Stater territory in Syria (Picture: PA)

Mr Hickman said the court also had to decide ‘whether the deprivation decision gave rise to a real risk of death or degrading and inhuman treatment’.

He said conditions in al-Roj and in the al-Hawl camp – from which Shamima was moved for her own safety in February – breached her human rights.

The decision to strip her of citizenship ‘had the effect and was designed to prevent’ Shamima from returning to the UK, leaving her ‘abandoned’ in a detention camp, he said.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He added this meant she ‘cannot have a fair and effective appeal’ as she is unable to speak confidentially with her lawyers or give evidence.

The Home Office’s barrister Jonathan Glasson QC argued in his written case that stripping Shamima of UK citizenship did not leave her stateless.

He argued she ‘was a Bangladeshi citizen by descent, in accordance with Bangladeshi law’.

He also submitted that she ‘has not been placed at risk of ill-treatment’ as a result of the decision to revoke her British citizenship.

Instead, he argued: ‘Any risk that the appellant does face arose, and continues to persist, as the result of the appellant having travelled to Syria and aligned with Isis and is wholly unrelated to the deprivation decision.’

Amira Abase, Kadiza Sultana and Shamima Begum at Gatwick Airport where they boarded a flight to Turkey (Picture: AFP/Getty)

Shamima was heavily pregnant when she was found in a refugee camp in Syria in February this year (Picture: ITV)

At 15 Shamima, alongside Kadiza Sultana, 16, and Amira Abase, 15, boarded a flight from Gatwick Airport to Istanbul, Turkey, on 17 February 2015, before making their way to Raqqa in Syria.

Shamima married Dutch convert Yago Riedijk 10 days after arriving in Isis territory, with her schoolfriends also reportedly marrying foreign jihadi fighters.

She told The Times in February that she left Raqqa in January 2017 with her husband but her children, a one-year-old girl and a three-month-old boy, had both since died.

Her third child died shortly after he was born.

Advertisement

Mrs Justice Elisabeth Laing is expected to reserve her judgment.
